## Volunteer Opportunities  Volunteering is a great way to gain valuable skills, make new friends, and help your community. Housing and Residence Life offers many opportunities for you to volunteer! Whether you’re looking to volunteer for our annual move-in to welcome on-campus residents, or an event or project for students in our on-campus community, we have many options for you to get involved!     ## Move Crew  We are seeking Move Crew volunteers to help us welcome our on-campus residents. Move Crew volunteers will greet students, unload items, and deliver student’s belongings to their rooms. We need your help for both of our Summer Bridge move-in days (August 14 and 15) as well as our traditional fall move-in days (August 21 and 22) . For more details and to sign up, please fill out our form using the link below.  Volunteer for Move Crew  [Volunteer for Move Crew](https://iu.co1.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_3f8jk9OAvDw1Dr8)  Please note: If you or your group have any volunteers who are not able to lift and move residents’ items, we still need your help. There several new Move Crew positions for those individuals and we will assign them based on the necessary accommodations. Please contact Madelin Willis ( willmade@iupui.edu ) if this applies to you or members in your group.     ### Move Crew FAQ   ## Will volunteers be required to wear masks?  Effective July 6, 2021, masks are optional within campus buildings for those who are fully vaccinated. Those who are exempt from the vaccine requirement or in the process of becoming fully vaccinated should continue to wear a mask inside buildings on campus. All individuals regardless of vaccination status will need to continue to wear a mask on public transportation, including campus buses, per guidelines from the Transportation Security Administration.     ## Will groups not affiliated with IUPUI be allowed to volunteer?  Yes. We welcome organizations from outside of the university to help us welcome students to campus. All organizations must be approved by Housing and Residence Life.     ## Will Housing and Residence Life be providing t-shirts for volunteers?  This year HRL is unable to provide t-shirts for volunteers. Volunteers are encouraged to wear shirts that highlight the organization they are volunteering, provided that the apparel is appropriate and not otherwise objectionable. Volunteers are also welcome to wear IUPUI spirit wear.     ## What are the shift times for the move-in days?  Move Crew shifts for each day are 8:30 a.m. to 3:30 p.m.  Based on how many students sign up for move-in times on each day, shifts may end earlier than 3:30 p.m. Volunteers who are not able to stay for the full shift need to notify Madelin Willis ( willmade@iupui.edu ) beforehand.     ## How will Move Crew volunteers be identified?  Each volunteer will be provided a wristband for each day of move-in. While assisting parents and students, all volunteers should be wearing the wristbands.     ## Is food provided for volunteers?  We will have water and individually packaged snacks available for Move Crew volunteers. Volunteers will be assigned a 30-minute break during their shift where they can relax and eat in the Move Crew break room at the facility they are volunteering.     ### Promotional opportunities for your organization:  In order to help promote all of the groups/organizations that volunteer for Move Crew we will be providing a couple of new opportunities for getting information to residents. ## Break Information  Break periods throughout the academic year are important times for students to relax, renew focus on their academics, and catch up with friends and family back home. Information about each break period is listed below. For more information, please contact your community office.   ## Fall Break  During fall break, residents are permitted to stay on campus as this period is included in the rental rate. No additional registration is needed for this break period.     ## Thanksgiving Break  During this break period, residents can choose to remain on campus and there are no additional rental fees or registrations for staying on-campus during this timeframe.  All housing offices will be closed Wednesday through Friday of this break and community offices will be closed Monday through Friday. It is important to plan accordingly during this period if you are expecting important items to ship, as deliveries during this time won't be received.     ## Winter Break  Ball Residence Hall, University Tower, and North Hall will close for winter break . During this period, residents are not required to remove their belongings; however, they will not be able to re-enter their residence hall until after these buildings re-open for spring semester. Residents may move back into the halls beginning Friday January 6 at 8am.  Riverwalk Apartments and Shared Suite residents may stay during winter break, as this period is included as part of their housing contract.  Community offices for all facilities will be closed during the break.  If you are expecting important packages to ship during that timeframe, please plan accordingly .  If you have an emergency work order or facility issue, please call the RA on duty regardless of the time of day.  If you are locked out or require the assistance of a staff member, please expect the staff member to take longer to arrive, depending on your location and the facility the staff member is coming from.  Students who are locked out during winter break are subject to a $50 lockout fee instead of the standard $15 fee.   ## Spring Break  During spring break, residents are permitted to stay on campus as this period is included in the rental rate. No additional registration is needed for this break period.   ### Resident Quick Links  Submit a Work Order Resident Handbook  [Submit a Work Order](https://housing.iupui.edu/residents/submit-workorder.html)  [Resident Handbook](https://housing.iupui.edu/residents/residential-handbook/index.html)

## Residential Curriculum  We care about more than just providing the facilities for premier on-campus urban living.  We care about providing you with a high quality on-campus living and learning experience.  ​When you choose to live with us, you gain unique access to an environment that supports your development in and out of the classroom. You will build connections that celebrate differences, foster community, and promote personal and community responsibility.   ### As a result of focusing on these categories of learning, the residential experience has improved.  2,700 The number of conversations RAs had with residents about our learning goals  95% The percentage of students who reported having at least an okay or great roommate relationship  300 The number of activities hosted by RAs that supported learning and connection   ### Our plan for what you will learn, emphasizes four topics   ##### Personal Responsibility  You will be able to assume responsibility for your individual experience by applying values to your decision making.   ##### Interpersonal Communication  You will build relationships, actively solve problems, and resolve conflicts through understanding communication styles to accomplish personal and relational goals.   ##### Identity Development  You will identify social and personal identities, understand your positionality with the development of self and others identities, and learn how to practice social justice advocacy in your residential, IUPUI, and Indianapolis communities.   ##### Community Engagement  You will make connections with others within your residential, IUPUI, and Indianapolis communities. You will be introduced to the complexity of social issues and make positive contributions.   ### RAs serve as peer educators  A resident assistant’s job responsibilities include managing safety and security of the community and serving a resource for students on campus, but the RAs also serve another important role in the community. They are role models and peer educators. As someone who is also navigating the college experience, they can provide you a helpful perspective as you settle into life on campus. RAs coordinate and support the residential curriculum by having conversations and hosting activities and events where you can gain skills in our four learning goals.  Keeping their role of peer educator at the forefront, see what some of our RAs commit to for their residents:   ### Connections to IUPUI PLUS  We are committed to furthering your educational pursuits both inside and outside of the classroom. For this reason, our residential curriculum was designed keeping in mind IUPUI’s Profiles of Learning for Undergraduate Success . The Profiles of Learning for Undergraduate Success prepare you to communicate, innovate, solve problems, and contribute to local and global communities.  [Profiles of Learning for Undergraduate Success](https://profiles.iupui.edu/index.html)  In our work with our residential curriculum, the learning experiences we promote also support co-curricular activities on campus, the general education program, and even major- and minor-specific course work.  Personal Responsibility support’s the Profile’s focus on students being a Problem Solver.  Interpersonal Communication directly connects to the Profile’s focus on students being a Communicator.  Identity Development and Community Engagement build upon one another to support the Profile’s focus on students leaving IUPUI to become Community Contributors .   ### Learn more about how we support your success or apply today! As a student staff member, you're generally expected to spend at least 15-20 hours per week on your floor or in your building, but that is only a guideline. Your floor or building is your home, and you and your fellow staff members are responsible for developing the community environment in that home. In addition to individual supervisor meetings and training in August and January, RAs have staff meetings every Tuesday night from 9:00pm-11:00pm. RAs are also on-call (or on duty) at least once a week where they must be in their community, conduct rounds, and be available for residents.   ## How many positions are available?  Based on our anticipated occupancy for the 2024-2025 academic year, we will have 50 RA positions, 4 SJRA positions, and 6 FA positions available. These numbers include both new and returning staff members. Our current staff do not express interest in continuing their employment until late January.   ## Am I able to participate in co-curricular activities or have a non-housing position on campus? Outside obligations that require you to track your hours, via the university time system (Kuali) or on paper, will be approved on a case-by-case basis. This may include, but is not limited to, on-campus jobs, internships, leadership positions, work-study positions, and some scholarship based employment. Co-curricular activities or leadership positions that do not require you to track your hours for pay are acceptable as long as they do not impede your ability to complete the RA job expectations.   ## When do I have to be back to school in August? Ultimately, the more flexible you are, the more chances you will have to be placed. However, we ask that you are honest in your community preferences and only select communities in which you will accept an RA role.   ## What is included in the compensation package? Every student’s financial aid situation is different. RAs are employed for one term at a time and may reapply for up to two additional terms. A term is identified as one academic year, so i t is possible for you to serve three terms as an RA. ## About Us  On-campus housing has been part of this campus well before the official formation of IUPUI in 1969.  In fact, the Department of Housing was originally established 11 years prior in 1958, and on-campus housing has been traced back to 1914 when nine nursing students first moved into Long Hospital.  Current housing options span quite an array of history and amenities when it comes to traditional campus housing.  Take a look at the history of our buildings:     ## Ball Residence Hall  Ball Residence Hall was originally built in 1928 as additional on-campus housing made possible by a gift from the Ball brothers of Muncie, Indiana.  In the original construction, Ball Hall featured a gymnasium, library, offices, and house-mother apartments as well as class rooms and laboratories. Still today, remnants of these original features and the classic architecture of 1928 can be seen throughout the residence hall.  Ball Annex was later constructed in two phases to provide additional housing for the student nurses.  The first two floors were constructed in 1945 followed by the third and fourth floors in 1957.  In the summer of 2013 Ball Hall received several facility upgrades including a lobby renovation, new resident furniture in every room, and every resident room was repainted.  Ball Hall is now undergoing a 16.7 million dollar renovation which will include adding air conditioning to the resident rooms, newly constructed bathrooms, and updates to the building's infastructure.     ## Riverwalk Apartments   ## University Tower  University Tower, formerly the University Place Hotel, was once a four diamond hotel and conferencing staple in downtown Indianapolis.  With the increasing demand for on-campus student housing and classroom space, and the need to reassess the viability of continuing hotel and conference center operations, the decision to convert this facility from a hotel and conference center to first-year student housing, classroom space, and a traditional university dining facility was announced in the spring of 2012 with approximately 14 months to prepare for its inaugural first-year class to move in for fall of 2013.     ## North Hall
